hedline.hl1: Man Tried To Push Four In Subways, Police Say

abstract.p: Vagrant identified as Paul O'Dwywer tries to push four waiting passengers onto tracks at two subway stations in downtown Manhattan; all four are safe 9S)

block.p: A homeless man tried to push four waiting passengers onto the tracks at two subway stations yesterday in downtown Manhattan, but all four survived the attacks, the police said.

The first attack occurred shortly before noon at the West Fourth Street subway station in Greenwich Village. A 20-year-old woman managed to save herself from falling in front of an approaching train only by keeping an iron grip on a platform pillar until an onlooker intervened, approaching the attacker from behind and kicking him, officials said. As the woman fled, the assailant boarded a train.
A homeless man tried to push four waiting passengers onto the tracks at two subway stations yesterday in downtown Manhattan, but all four survived the attacks, the police said.

The first attack occurred shortly before noon at the West Fourth Street subway station in Greenwich Village. A 20-year-old woman managed to save herself from falling in front of an approaching train only by keeping an iron grip on a platform pillar until an onlooker intervened, approaching the attacker from behind and kicking him, officials said. As the woman fled, the assailant boarded a train.

The police said that 20 minutes later, the attacker, whom they identified as Paul O'Dwyer, 47, individually attacked two women and a man, trying to push them to the tracks at the Broadway-Lafayette Street station. The police said no trains were approaching at the time.
The man who was attacked alerted the police. The officers found Mr. O'Dwyer, who was carrying a plastic bag full of clothing, on the platform near a girder, the police said.
When the officers called the police dispatcher, they learned that Mr. O'Dwyer fit the description of the man in the earlier attack, the police said.

Mr. O'Dwyer was admitted to Bellevue Hospital Center after a psychiatric evaluation, then was placed back in police custody. The police said Mr. O'Dwyer was charged with assault, reckless endangerment and unlawful imprisonment.
The attacks happened more than a year after Kendra Webdale was pushed to her death in front of a subway train by Andrew Goldstein, who had been in and out of the mental health system for years.
But Mr. O'Dwyer did not appear to have a similar history. Roger Klingman, a spokesman for the State Office of Mental Health, said Mr. O'Dwyer had not been admitted to any state mental health centers.
The police said that Mr. O'Dwyer had no criminal record in the city, and did not immediately appear to have a history of violence.
